content: okay nothing original this week just a
mashup of a couple ideas I saw out there then I put together to come up with the
thing that I was trying to do I wanted a nice set of generic plateaus to use for
my war games and also for my role-playing games to make like canyons
and things like that and I wanted him to look generic enough that they'd look
good at any play Matt serve in any environment so I was experimenting with
paint schemes as well and here's what I came up with so the texturing of the
sides the hills to look like rocks came from a channel called painting is my
life not sure if it's a defunct now but there's a link in the description below
and as for the kinds of shapes to make as well as the use of pebble piles that
came from winters SEO again link in the description below to great ideas working
with one-inch thick extruded polystyrene also known as home insulation draw and
cut out the desired shapes using your knife or a hot wire table with your
knife strike at the side like this about three to five times in a given area
and work your way around the whole slab like that then striking it
perpendicularly about every centimeter or so maybe varying the angle of the
knife slightly then take your metal ruler or a dull butter knife something
like that and rasp at the edges you'll have to apply a bit of pressure but you
can see the material start to shred and chunk away immediately use your hand to
just clean up and knock off any loose bits and voila you get a nice exposed
stone substrate look for attaching pieces together hot glue no messing
around no need for toothpicks just some lines of hot glue very strong
bond instant move right along with the project
nice thick undiluted coat of white PVA glue Elmer's glue-all does just fine in
cover with sand this is quikrete construction sand which
has a nice mixture of very fine to very coarse aggregate 50-pound bag was about
four bucks lifetime supply then go ahead and squeeze some pools of white glue up
against the level changes like this and dump some aquarium pebbles on them let
it dry overnight just give it a full 12 hours black balm with cheap acrylic
craft paint I prefer Americana and then gray plain
old craft smart gray no working up from darker Gray's no washes no messing about
just gray we're just gonna dry brush this on load the brush with paint and
then work most of that paint right off on the palette like you see me doing
here and then begin lightly attacking the piece actually you can strike at the
sides pretty strongly you'll want some decent coverage there but all the
horizontals sanded surfaces start lightly and give it a light even dusting
and go at different angles to help with the uniformity
now again dry brushing but this time
with golden brown and we're only gonna strike a few spots this is just to give
a hint of color a hint of variation it's subtle but it makes a difference
and lastly optional plain white again a dry brush but this is incredibly light
in fact I really only Knick the tops of the pebble piles and there may be a
couple strikes on the sand but I can't emphasize this enough go light dry
brushing with white can easily get away from you and overpower all your
undertones and you end up with a dusty looking mess this is a subtle subtle
application and finally got some moss from the crafting store gonna use this
tan colored stuff and just pick a few spots where the level changes hot glue a
tough down there alright guys now stick with me here
through the end I'm gonna show you some construction photos and then I'm gonna
show you what I mean by these fitting on any surface so here's they are this is
the sand drying do assembly-line these it's good for your mental health here
they are finished all laid out this is all of them they've
served me well so if you want to see what a complete set looks like that
space marine is on a thirty two millimeter base for scale here's a
close-up of the different geometries and different sizes mix it up again winters
SEO got to thank him for that awesome video here it is on an Alpine
like tundra mat this is one of my frontline gaming mats love my frontline
gaming mats you can see they match that poke through that rock that's on the
ground so I look great here while we're at it I figured I just throw some miles
down and show you the height really adds a lot to the game once I built these art
games got much more interesting I think here's a close-up of a stepped bigger
one and get creative you know stack them here's an overpass kind of thing and the
fate figures fed underneath so you can get even more scenic here it is on the
Meadows great contrast here I think you can imagine like canyons or a lush
Valley or something like that and don't be afraid to group these together like I
have here to make even bigger masses of cliffs you know if
you if you push them together at just the right angle you'll always find that
they kind of even if you didn't plan it there's some that'll just fit together
nicely and here it is in a desert again fits right in especially with those
Tufts so this is arranged in a canyon like a gauntlet or maybe there's an
ambush it's gonna happen and this is one of their newer ones irradiated plains
love it just got it a few weeks ago and it is really really cool it's a very
vibrant in person using the terrible camera all this stuff is very vibrant in
person looks great this is actually just before we were about to kick off a game
of grim dark future my wife and I we're gonna play those little portals and the
giant crystals those were in recent episodes I forget which one I'll throw a
card on the screen if you're interested in making those so this was the Eldar
verse necron and i figure while we're here i'm you've gone this far might as
well show off my recently finished tear in it Parma so again irradiated plains
front-line gaming Matt's love them a lot of airbrush work on these and I tried a
satin varnish instead of matte I know that's the conventional wisdom and I've
I've always used matte but I figured they're bugs and maybe if they looked
greasy or slimy or something it might work and in real life I think it does
this camera picks up a little bit of extra shine they're not quite they're
not as shiny as they appear to be and my hive tyrunt kind of messed up the wings
out here I got overspray all over the fingers they're on the outside of the
wing but again the height of these adds a lot to the game my buddy who's played
for like 20 years but not really into terrain and I'm the opposite I'm new but
really into terrain has really praised these taking our games to the next level
for all you 3d printers out there don't forget to check out heroes hoard where
you can get true tiles models as well as a ton of other excellent fantasy related
scenery Oh My Luck thank you for joining me and
I'll see you next time
